title: Laughing OnLine
dek: Exploring the usage, evolution, and perception of digital laughter.
series: A four-part series on the usage, evolution, and perception of digital laughter.

parts.title: You rank it
parts.description: As with most lingo, the intent and perception of each laugh varies from person to person. Help us do some casual science to get a sense of how you use some of the most common laughs compared to other internet people.

intro.value: Laughter is complex. Even IRL it is hard to tell real ones and fake ones apart. Online, it is even harder with fewer visual cues and a wider range of tools to express laughter. As internet language develops, new forms of laughter spread like a cold in a classroom. If you are stuck on the ‚Äúha‚Äùs and ‚Äúlol‚Äùs of days past, consider this your guide to the present. This is the perception and evolution of the digital laugh.

rank.instructions1: Pick a laugh. Not familiar? Skip it!
rank.instructions2: Tell us how funny something really is when you use

scale.text: Unamused, not smiling; perhaps even feeling spiteful.
Neutral. Used as filler or to be nice. No physical response.
A single breath of air exits the mouth, a possible smile forms.
Visibly amused. Puffs of air released, slight body giration.
Laughing so much that breathing is hard; actually rofl-ing.

notes.value: Questions or comments? sup@pudding.cool. This story was published in October 2019. Thanks to Jan Diehm for some design love.

method.value: Aggregated user survey data is updated live every 10 minutes.
